Philosophizing With Others?
4. Philosophizing With Others?

Philosophy for Children encourages children to think for
themselves at the same time that it encourages them to think
with others. However, philosophy is often viewed as more a
matter of solitary reflection, perhaps involving exchanges between a
few other solitary thinkers—something to which the
“masses” are neither privy nor attracted. Perhaps many
would claim that this is philosophy at its best. Even if this were so
(a controversial view), it would not undermine arguments for including
philosophy in the K-12 curricula. However esoteric physics and
mathematics at their best may be, the schools nevertheless recognize
the importance of making these subjects available in some form to all
students. Similarly, Philosophy for Children advocates can counter
that there should be a place for all students—whether labelled
“gifted and talented,” “underachieving,” or
“ordinary”—pursuing philosophical questions
together.

For this to work, it must be possible for children in the classroom to
engage in sustained philosophical discussion with others. As already
noted, Gareth Matthew’s writings provide ample evidence that
children are capable of having interesting, if not profound,
philosophical thoughts. Less obvious, however, is children’s
ability to sustain and develop this with others. Anecdotes of young
children spontaneously sharing a philosophical thought with an
observant adult are not sufficient. Matthews’ Dialogues With
Children provides good evidence that children can go well beyond
this. Other examples of substantial philosophical conversations of
children found in Lone (2012, 2021), McCall (2009), Pritchard (1996,
2022), Shapiro (2012), and Wartenberg (2009, 2013), among many others,
should leave little doubt that children have this ability.
